Award.AwardTitle: Soil-Foundation-Structure Interaction Effects on Cyclic Failure Potential of Silts and Clays

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Earthquake-induced ground failure has resulted in billions of dollars of damage during recent earthquakes. For example, the Canterbury earthquake sequence resulted in $40 billion in losses (over 20% of New Zealand GDP) in Christchurch, New Zealand, with much of this loss attributed to liquefaction of loose saturated sandy soil. Entire communities were relocated following the earthquake sequence as "red-zones" were declared in regions of high liquefaction hazard. Soils can be broadly characterized as exhibiting either "sand-like" or "clay-like" behavior with respect to strength loss during earthquakes. Liquefaction of "sand-like" soils is due to reductions of interparticle contact stresses, and transfer of stress from the soil particles to fluid occupying the space between particles. A large number of case histories of liquefaction of "sand-like" soils has enabled engineers to develop procedures for predicting its occurrence. By contrast, the mechanisms of failure of "clay-like" soils are more poorly understood, though there are cases in which such failures have resulted in damage to structures. In fact, cyclic failure of "fine-grained" soils are often constrained to the regions beneath structures, and not in the free-field soils away from the structures. There is a significant need to better understand the conditions for which "clay-like" soils may fail during earthquakes. Forging such an understanding will require new knowledge in the fundamental cyclic behavior of "clay-like" soils combined with knowledge of the cyclic stresses imposed on the soil beneath structures during earthquake shaking. This project will enable engineers to better predict conditions for which cyclic failure of "clay-like" soil will and will not occur during earthquakes. This will enhance public safety by reducing the risk of future structural failures. The research project will result in a publicly accessible database containing all of the experimental data so that future researchers will be able to benefit from the experiments. Furthermore, the project team will engage under-represented students through the UCLA Center for Excellence in Engineering and Diversity (CEED) through a hands-on project-oriented course for engineering freshman, and through the RISE-UP (Research Intensive Series in Engineering for Under-represented Populations) program.

The project will achieve its technical objectives by developing an understanding of the influence of Soil-Foundation-Structure Interaction (SFSI) on cyclic ground failure potential. The project activities include: (1) development of elasto-dynamic solutions quantifying the amplitude and phase of stresses induced by SFSI, and deployment of these solutions in a web-based tool for public use; (2) laboratory testing of fine-grained soil samples to evaluate variations of liquefaction susceptibility with soil plasticity and more advanced indicators of soil behavior (i.e., strength normalization) for the purpose of designing the centrifuge modeling experiments, (3) centrifuge modeling studies involving single-degree-of-freedom structures resting atop variable-plasticity fine-grained soil deposits, and (4) a simplified procedure for analyzing triggering of cyclic failure and the resulting settlements. Currently, the influence of SFSI is nearly entirely neglected when assessing ground failure potential due to a lack of understanding of key aspects of behavior, and a lack of tools available for engineers to incorporate SFSI effects . The primary intellectual merit of the project will be to enhance understanding of these fundamental issues.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earthquake-induced ground failure has resulted in billions of dollars of damage during recent earthquakes. Engineers assess earthquake-induced ground failure potential using procedures developed for "free-field" conditions involving level ground far away from structures. However, recent earthquakes have shown that ground failure often occurs beneath structures due to the increment of stress imposed on the ground by the vibrating structure due to soil-foundation-structure interaction (SFSI). This deficiency is driven by a lack of high quality observations of the influence of structures on ground failure, and by the lack of a formal analysis procedure for quantifying SFSI stresses. The purpose of this project was to address this data gap, and formulate a methodology for assessing soil-foundation-structure interaction effects of earthquake-induced ground failure.

Intellectual Merit

This research has resulted in numerous Project Outcomes. First, a high quality experimental dataset utilizing centrifuge model testing to study cyclic failure of fine-grained soils beneath structures was developed and made publicly available through the DesignSafe cyberinfrastructure. Experimental data is often made publicly available through a file repository with a static data report describing the data, but this project took public accessibility to a new level. We developed our data reports as interactive Jupyter notebooks that enable users to immediately view and interact with our experimental data. Furthermore, users can copy the notebooks as a starting point for data reuse, and subsequently modify the notebook to satisfy their own specific objectives. Numerous other researchers have contacted us about these Jupyter notebooks, and have begun using these tools in their research workflows.

Second, an analytical framework was developed to account for the influence of structures on ground failure. The framework utilizes elastic stress solutions to quantify initial conditions and shaking demands, and quantifies the factor of safety against failure, or alternatively quantifies mobilized shear strains that translate directly to structural settlement and rotation. This is a significant contribution to geotechnical earthquake engineering because it provides a means for engineers to overcome the current limitations in existing ground failure analysis procedures that assume "free-field" conditions. Analysis of the centrifuge model tests using the new procedure agrees quite well with observations of structural settlement and rotation. By contrast, traditional "free-field" ground failure analysis methods do not agree well with the centrifuge test data, highlighting limitations of the existing methods that are commonly utilized. This research has resulted in a new validated analysis framework that will improve the manner in which engineers evaluate earthquake-induced ground failure, thereby reducing earthquake-induced damage to the built environment.

Broader Impacts

In addition to the intellectual merit of the completed work, there have also been significant broader impacts. Two PhD students worked on this project, both of whom have now graduated. Additionally, we trained two Civil and Environmental undergraduate students at UCLA through the REU program during the summer of 2018, immediately after their first year at UCLA. Both students have achieved at a high level in their courses and are leaders in various student groups and projects. We also trained a group of five undergraduate students in the Engineering 87 course in Fall 2016. The E87 course is organized by our Center for Excellence in Engineering and Diversity, and provides a hands-on experience to under-represented undergraduate students during their first quarter at UCLA. The program has proven effective in developing a strong engineering identity among participants at a time when the curriculum is dominated by math, chemistry, and physics rather than engineering courses. All five of the students who participated that quarter graduated in 2020, having received commencement awards, completed summer research internships all over the world, and working as local engineers. This is a truly remarkable group of students who got off to a good start at UCLA in their E87 course.

 


Last Modified: 07/02/2020
Modified by: Scott J Brandenberg

Engineers assess earthquake-induced ground failure potential using procedures developed for "free-field" conditions involving level ground far away from structures. However, recent earthquakes have shown that ground failure often occurs beneath structures due to the increment of stress imposed on the ground by the vibrating structure due to soil-foundation-structure interaction (SFSI). The purpose of this project was to address this data gap, and formulate a methodology for assessing soil-foundation-structure interaction effects of earthquake-induced ground failure. Intellectual Merit This research has resulted in numerous Project Outcomes. First, a high quality experimental dataset utilizing centrifuge model testing to study cyclic failure of fine-grained soils beneath structures was developed and made publicly available through the DesignSafe cyberinfrastructure. We developed our data reports as interactive Jupyter notebooks that enable users to immediately view and interact with our experimental data. Numerous other researchers have contacted us about these Jupyter notebooks, and have begun using these tools in their research workflows. Analysis of the centrifuge model tests using the new procedure agrees quite well with observations of structural settlement and rotation. This research has resulted in a new validated analysis framework that will improve the manner in which engineers evaluate earthquake-induced ground failure, thereby reducing earthquake-induced damage to the built environment. Two PhD students worked on this project, both of whom have now graduated. Both students have achieved at a high level in their courses and are leaders in various student groups and projects. We also trained a group of five undergraduate students in the Engineering 87 course in Fall 2016. The E87 course is organized by our Center for Excellence in Engineering and Diversity, and provides a hands-on experience to under-represented undergraduate students during their first quarter at UCLA.
